timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure this one can be a cache, since we cannot necessarily recompute whether we've already injected.
If we can safely detection prior failed injection, then we could use a cache.
However, I think a WeakMap is probably the better choice here.
timeline.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: Since the Callable allocation is only down the slow-path, I think this is fine.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText: I would also prefer to use different class as a supplier and avoid creating new anonymous instance just to pass a parameter to cache supplier. But If we using guava Cache interface underneath, this anonymous callable will be created at some point anyway; or we will have to do get and put inside a critical section again (eg: https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-java/blob/master/dd-java-agent/agent-bootstrap/src/main/java/datadog/trace/bootstrap/WeakMap.java#L120 )
replies.author: lpriima

timeline.bodyText: Why remove this interface and switch to passing the Callable in?  Seems like an unnecessary tradeoff.
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: This class stores two unrelated abstractions: matcher and cache supplier. I was trying to split them. The actual interface of supplier was not that important for me. But looks like we will be able to remove WeakMap.ValueSupplier after this change.
replies.author: lpriima

replies.bodyText:
Yes, I don't really like classes implementing an extra interface like Supplier.  I think it is generally better to have an internal object for that purpose instead.
As for Callable vs our own interface.  I don't think it matters too much, but we typically avoid adding additional abstractions when the JDK classes suffice.  I don't see why this would be any different.
In short, I'm happy with the change.
replies.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: did you figure this out?
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: didn't figure out why. But definitely logic is expected to be like this in tests. If I use direct cache.get(key, valueSuppler) then tests are failing
replies.author: lpriima

replies.bodyText:
I was thinking about another detail related to critical sections yesterday.
I think doing the computation inside the critical section might be a bad idea in general.
My thinking is that it increases the amount of activity under lock including likely taking other locks.  In other words, it increases our potential for deadlocks.  I'm not sure how much it increases our exposure, but it is strictly an increase.
replies.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: This class is referenced directly by instrumentation so it needs to be in the bootstrap project.  Guava should not be though, this is why we have WeakMap.Provider.
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText:
Hmm, that makes sense -- and maybe, following WeakMap.Provider is the right choice for now.
I'm a little worried that the way our instrumentation is currently structured obscures the requirements for injecting into ClassLoaders particularly the bootstrap.  I'm actually increasingly thinking we shouldn't inject into the bootstrap at all, but that's a separate matter.
I also don't like the swapping of the Provider at runtime required by WeakMap.Provider and others.  I'd prefer to see something immutable if possible -- perhaps via ServiceLoader.  Right now, a call at start-up provides a different result than later on -- given that the concurrency properties of the WeakMap are crucial, I find that too subtle and problematic.
As alternative, we could have WeakCache find a Provider by searching the instrumentation ClassLoader using ServiceLoader.
replies.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText:
I'm wondering a general 10 min expiration works; I think it does.
Our main cache control should be size -- and we're forcing all callers to specify, so I think this is fine.
Maybe we should also provide an option to specify initialSize, but I think this is reasonable starting point.
timeline.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: I assuming we still need to run this through googleJavaFormat, since I think it would make most of these parameters final.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText: I don't think that's a googleJavaFormat thing, but specific to our recommended Idea configuration.
replies.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: ok
replies.author: lpriima

timeline.bodyText: I assume in this case that we can recompute, so this should be fine.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText:
https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-java/pull/1256/files#diff-4af6c77e2e2da192a5bf9abf9298c074R22
keeping as is so far. because change is getting to big already
replies.author: lpriima

timeline.bodyText:
I'm not sure we should have a newWeakCache that doesn't require specifying size.
Basically, I'm not sure there's a one size fits all or most for this, but maybe, there is.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText: default is unlimited size
replies.author: lpriima

replies.bodyText:
introduce custom size parameter:
https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-java/pull/1256/files#diff-f371393c051827398efcd93779e801deR35
keeping as is so far, because change getting too big:
https://github.com/DataDog/dd-trace-java/pull/1256/files#diff-4af6c77e2e2da192a5bf9abf9298c074R22
replies.author: lpriima

replies.bodyText:
My thinking is that we keep the WeakMap for non-evicting unlimited cases.  WeakCache should always evict -- and people need to write code with that in mind.
We should also strictly prefer WeakCache over WeakMap whenever possible.
replies.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText:
Is this effectively another cache?
I guess don't yet a notion of a non-weak cache, but maybe, we should.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText: it's just how it was before
replies.author: lpriima

timeline.bodyText:
I know this is pre-existing and a bit subjective.
However, I would prefer to see ConcurrentMap rather than Map here to make the thread coordination a bit more clear.
timeline.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: PreparedStatements can be reused forever.  These entries can't expire.  I believe this needs to be a WeakMap.  Connections can also be reused but I think that codepath rebuilds DBInfo if its not in the map.
timeline.author: randomanderson

replies.bodyText: changed back
replies.author: lpriima

timeline.bodyText: Why Object key rather than K key?
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText:
it's pretty much was a copy from guava Cache:
https://github.com/google/guava/blob/0cd4e9faa1360da4a343f84cb275d6eda0c5e732/guava/src/com/google/common/cache/Cache.java#L49
I was trying to find why it's done like this in guava and didn't find any reason, why they not using K there. They doesn't seems to care about compatibility with JDK versions before 5. Like in JDK There is always a some form of get method accepting Object in all types of map interfaces:
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Map.html#get-java.lang.Object-
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/AbstractMap.html#get-java.lang.Object-
replies.author: lpriima

replies.bodyText: Yes, I'm aware that Java maps do something similar.  I think we can leave it as is.  I was mostly just curious.
replies.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: We should probably treat having more that one supplier as an IllegalState.
timeline.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText:
Do we need the NoOp?  Or, would it better to just raise an IllegalStateException immediately?
I'm usually in favor of failing fast when possible.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.author: lpriima

timeline.bodyText: I like the moving of the factory onto AgentTooling.  I think that's a good call given the inherent coupling.
timeline.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: Thanks for doing that clean-up
timeline.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: So accessing the Provider directly inside the Instrumentation?  I think I like that.
timeline.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: I think I'd prefer that encapsulated a bit more.  As is, that ServiceLoader look-up is a lot to process.
timeline.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: Yes, I'd prefer to create a static factory to wrap the look-up, so we don't have to repeat this.
timeline.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText: Right now we already have several (e.g.: netty-4.0 and netty-4.1) no-dependency artifacts with a lot of copy-paste inside. If we try to move common code to separate module, the muzzle tests will fail. Do we want to make this changes inside this PR ?
replies.author: lpriima

replies.bodyText:
I see.
Yes, I think part of our problem is that helper class system doesn't transitively handle parents, etc. automatically.  I think that ends up discouraging reuse, but we shouldn't solve that now.
I was more wondering whether we could put a static look-up method on WeakCache or WeakCache.Provider that handles the ServiceLoader logic.  I suppose that has the problem of needing to find the right ClassLoader.  Hmm?
replies.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: I don't think this class can use a cache semantic.  The reason this exists is because netty will throw an error if an attribute of the same name is created more than once.  (See the comment in the class.)
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: Maybe just cache without time eviction ? only by weak reference expiration
replies.author: lpriima

replies.bodyText: Conceptually, I don't think of WeakReference expiration as eviction per se.  From the standpoint of retrieving something from the Map/Cache, WeakReference expiration isn't an observable difference.  Only the side effect on memory is observable.
replies.author: dougqh

replies.bodyText:
I don't think this class can use a cache semantic. The reason this exists is because netty will throw an error if an attribute of the same name is created more than once. (See the comment in the class.)

That doesn't necessarily mean that cache won't work, but it depends on the nature of the error.  If Netty fails fast and in recoverable way, then we could simply handle the exception rather than introducing a side structure.
replies.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: Same problem here...
timeline.author: tylerbenson

timeline.bodyText: This is implied for fields on an interface, so this doesn't change anything.
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: that's true. Do you want me to revert it back ? it's just a  style question
replies.author: lpriima

replies.bodyText: I'm fine with dropping public, but I'm less keen on dropping static.  And final is a useful implied addition.
replies.author: dougqh

timeline.bodyText: How expensive is loadWeakCacheProvider()?  Is this something we should be concerned about?
timeline.author: tylerbenson

replies.bodyText: Yes, I was pondering that.  I think it would be good to have the Provider captured by a static final, so we don't keep reloading it.

replies.bodyText: Is that a side effect of our prior change in this area?  But yes, we should clean-up the naming.
